author: sky.cactus
content: I would like to see data on why 1 is too low for normal.  3 feels *way* too high to me for the vast majority of blocks.  There are some outliers, but you definitely shouldn't set the minimum based on "average".

author: .vbuterin
content: yeah, agree with this

author: sky.cactus
content: All of the research I have seen (where people actually did modelling) suggests that 1 is "more than enough" if you don't consider MEV, and 2 should outstrip the vast majority of MEV containing blocks.

author: .vbuterin
content: Wait, is this arguing about what a fair premium is?

author: .vbuterin
content: I don't think it's correct that you need a premium to compensate for MEV revenue

author: .vbuterin
content: Because in "the normal case", the whole point is that transactions no longer compete with other transactions, they merely compete with the basefee cost of including them

author: .vbuterin
content: So you including my transaction does not reduce your ability to get more MEV revenue

author: .vbuterin
content: personally I expect premiums will settle down to something like 1 gwei + 10%

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah.

author: .vbuterin
content: the percentage component being inevitable because of (i) desire for higher prioritization in unexpected congestion, and (ii) miners exercising some inevitable degree of oligopoly pressure

author: sky.cactus
content: MEV matters because a block that is worth 100 ETH should (rationally) have a much higher minimum because the cost of an uncle goes up.

author: .vbuterin
content: aaah I see

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm then in that case, the premium would be proportional to known MEV revenue + estimated not-yet-known MEV revenue

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: On the note of uncle risk for including transactions, see: https://www.bitcoinunlimited.info/resources/feemarket.pdf

author: sky.cactus
content: In theory the optimal strategy is for a miner to iteratively build a block, adding transactions and noting their gains each step, until such time as the opportunity cost of adding the next transaction is lower than the uncle risk it adds.

author: .vbuterin
content: right

author: .vbuterin
content: although.... greedy algo is not necessarily optimal

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, block filling strategies are generally hard.

author: .vbuterin
content: you could have a case where late in block production a miner finds an MEV-heavy tx and that motivates them to rethink including a bunch of earlier txs

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are a miner and you are just going to pick a flat rate, I suspect that 1 or 2 is optimal.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, this is a far more advanced/hard thing to do though so I doubt we'll see it anytime soon.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe with flashbot-blocks soon we'll see some third parties do it though.

author: .vbuterin
content: right; the payoff relative to the coding effort is small, because MEV bursts are rare

author: lilonion4174
content: How do I like, make more money mining

author: butta
content: if everyone uses the same priority fee, tx ordering in a block would also be somewhat random

author: butta
content: donâ€™t think itâ€™s going to be a thing â€” weâ€™ll know more in a few hours ðŸ¤£

author: sky.cactus
content: Not random, first come first served, which is arguably *better* for ordering from a user's perspective.

author: butta
content: first come first served , why would a miner do that though?

author: fradamt
content: The order of most transactions is irrelevant to a miner, letting searchers find the ones that matter and not diving into some hard optimization problem otherwise seems like a better choice intuitively

author: fradamt
content: First come first serve is easiest and fastest, which is important to not raise uncle risk

author: p_bitfly
content: not really, it is like that until a nodes mempool is full (geth is currently capped at ~5000 tx by default) after that it will be random and depend on when your local node decides to rebroadcast your tx again

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be surprised to see 5000 transactions that are all eligible for inclusion in the mempool.

author: p_bitfly
content: check your geth node

author: p_bitfly
content:
```
> txpool.status
{
  pending: 5120,
  queued: 1024
}
```

author: p_bitfly
content: all pending are eligible for inclusion and the queued ones are currently not eligible

author: p_bitfly
content: also miners try to minimize the amount of pending tx they keep as it speeds up block generation

author: perama
content: Perhaps Micah meant surprised to see that *after the fork*. For a collection of eligible transactions will trigger sequential 30M gas blocks. I would expect the *pending* number to stabilise at 15M gas worth of transactions (~150 tx)  and for the queued number to become larger

author: p_bitfly
content: hm that would be even worse, so each node only keeps around 1024 queued tx

author: p_bitfly
content: meaning tx inclusion will get more random

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are using a sufficiently high base fee (just about everyone should be), then you essentially wouldn't sit in the queue in the vast majority of cases.

author: sky.cactus
content: You just submit your transaction and its included next block.

author: sky.cactus
content: The people who sit pending for extended periods are people with a base fee too low for inclusion *at all*, and those people can just re-submit when the base fee drops.

author: p_bitfly
content: ok so you submit a tx with a base fee of (current base fee * 2.03) and a miner tip of 2 GWei

author: p_bitfly
content: this means you will be compeding with all other tx that specify a tip of 2GWei for inclusion

author: p_bitfly
content: and if everybody uses the same miner tip (as suggested) this will cause lots of tx to pile up on the same miner tip amount

author: p_bitfly
content: but anyway in a few hours we will see how things develop

author: sky.cactus
content:
> compeding with all other tx that specify a tip of 2GWei for inclusion
Only if the block is 2x full, which is expected to be very rare.

author: sky.cactus
content: And when it does happen, it is not expected to last very long.  It should be extremely rare that it lasts for over 6 blocks (enough to make the 2.03x base fee not enough).

author: perama
content:
Another way to think about it is this:

Consider a situation where the base fee rose for some period and is now going to fall back to some reasonable value. 

The list of eligible transactions in the mempool in that situation is going to be less than 15M gas. 

Perhaps even zero, for it is part of the design that the basefee falls the most when blocks are *empty* (no eligible txs). 

It follows that the eligible list will be short on average.

author: p_bitfly
content: hm, shouldn't in this case geth's tx pool options be changed? to increase the storage of non-executable tx?

author: p_bitfly
content: currently the ratio is 5:1 (5120 executable tx, 1024 non-executable tx)

author: perama
content:
I think the limit is sane, but I have not maintained a mempool. 

The philosophy that a mempool is a place for a viable transaction appeals to me. Rather than a filing cabinet for a transaction in an hour. 

If the base fee falls and eats the 1024 nonviable transactions, then so be it, there are not enough paying customers at that price.

author: perama
content: By which I mean it seems safe, and data over the next few weeks will answer your question. I think it is tied to "what is the chance that there are prolonged sequence of empty blocks in a given day/week?" Such that increasing the mempool is worth the cost

author: p_bitfly
content: I believe it is more a question on how will users start to speed up their tx in case they get stuck

author: perama
content:
Oh sorry if I misunderstood.

Yes it will be interesting. There are some who think stuck transactions from low fees may now be a largely a relic of the past

author: sky.cactus
content: They are still *possible*, but if things are tuned correctly they should be very rare.

author: sky.cactus
content: TBD if the system is tuned correctly, it is very likely that it isn't tuned perfectly on the first shot though.  ðŸ™‚

author: lightclient
content: gm

author: timbeiko
content: Why would you _not_ take the average MEV revenue per block into account when calculating uncle risk?

author: timbeiko
content: Miners rationally shouldnâ€™t include a txn where the marginal fee isnâ€™t worth the uncle risk, and that includes losing the bundle, no?

author: timbeiko
content: Not all blocks have bundles (70% IIRC) and you donâ€™t want to offset MEV in every bundle, but something like 2-3 gwei offsets uncle risk for 50/90% of MEV blocks IIRC

author: timbeiko
content: So maybe you could use 1 for slow, 2 for normal or something

author: sky.cactus
content: Because almost all of the time it will be wrong.

author: sky.cactus
content: For blocks with low MEV, you want a low minimum premium.  For blocks with a very high amount of MEV, you want a pretty high minimum premium.

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, but that's hard to estimate

author: timbeiko
content: So aiming to beat ~50% of MEV blocks is a simple proxy for "I want to be included in 2 blocks"

author: sky.cactus
content: Since MEV isn't smooth, you have a lot of blocks with very little and a lot of blocks with a lot and for all of those you will be following a sub-optimal strategy.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even 2 I think is too high for most blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: IIRC (been a while), most blocks is just a bit over 1 for miner opportunity cost, including MEV.

author: sky.cactus
content: Without MEV it is below 1.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think a lot of people are often surprised how little high reward moves the premium.  Remember, 2 ETH leads to less than 1 nanoeth / gas premium to cover opportunity cost.  So a block with 2 more ETH in MEV (which I think is above average by quite a bit) would still not get you to 2.

author: barnabemonnot
content: the system is also somewhat stable if you take an upper bound of the priority fee that compensates MEV. If everyone is consistently bidding 5 Gwei priority fee rather than 2 Gwei, basefee will settle at 3 Gwei less than it would otherwise. this more than necessary going towards the block producer, but a user could bid less and if it was still above that BP's reserve price, the BP would include them, getting more out of the tx than other BPs who didn't include it

author: barnabemonnot
content: you're getting the ~~miner~~ uncle reward if not included so it's not exactly 2 you need to compensate for, rather 0.25?

author: barnabemonnot
content: (not saying it's desirable, I think we should still aim to minimise the priority fee, or the market will eventually do it for us anyways, so better to get the default right from the get go)

author: sky.cactus
content: You mean the uncle reward?

author: barnabemonnot
content: yes!

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, good point.  I always do forget about uncle rewards!

author: andi9314
content: I disagree. If we assume that the average user was someone who used to wait 1 min for his transaction to go through pre-1559, he will also be waiting roughly the same amount of time under 1559. We are not changing the average block size, so it can't be that everyone can now be included in the next block after 1559, unless 1559 reduces transaction demand. The average user will often find the base fee too high for him. He will just submit with lower base fee and wait for the base fee to go down, just as he submits with the "average" gas price pre-1559 and waits for his tx to go through.

author: sky.cactus
content: If the user is willing to pay significantly over the base fee then they will be included next block in most cases.  At the very least, they'll be included next block in at least 50% of cases.

author: sky.cactus
content: The big difference here is that a user can bid their willingness to pay and then pay the least amount possible for rapid inclusion.  This is quite different from having to try to bid *barely enough so you don't overpay*.

author: andi9314
content: 2x full block would happen whenever gas price is rapidly rising or jumping. Which is as expected, but I suspect it could happen even when gas isn't on a clear upward trend, because when the current block is expected to go above the target size, everyone knows the next block will have a higher fee, so they will try to get included in the current, cheaper block.

author: sky.cactus
content: That shouldn't change your maxFee setting.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe it would adjust your premium, but only for people watching very closely to the pending pool.

content: do we have liftoff??

author: andi9314
content: The casual user will still often have to overpay unless they are willing to sit and watch the basefee fluctuate for 1-3 minutes. They will submit with a basefee that will probably get them in under 3 minutes, with an average wait time of something like 1 minute. Sometimes, they will find that they get included immediately, whereas they would have been included soon enough with a lower basefee, meaning they overpaid for a quicker inclusion that they did not value much.

author: andi9314
content:
Fair point that they could just be trying not to overpay. I don't think they will likely get next block inclusion though unless they pay more than they used to, because we will still have the same average block size, so it's not possible to get more people in on average.
It's true that people in a given block will never overpay relative to others in the same block. But I suspect that basefee fluctuation will still lead to people to effectively overpay for a slightly faster inclusion that they did not want to pay for.

author: andi9314
content:
I don't think the series of 100% - 0% blocks will stabilize even when people switch to 1559 transactions. There will always be variation in the market because of fluctuation in demand (NFT cats) and fluctuation in supply (the time it takes to mine a block). When people start expecting the current block to be larger than 50%, they expect the next block to have a higher base fee, and so they want to get included in the current block. In fact, they will be willing to pay the miner a higher tip, sometimes even up to 1/8 of the current base fee, to get in the current block rather than the next one. So current block becomes 100% full.
Likewise for empty blocks. When the current block is expected to be less than 50% full, everyone expects the next block to have a lower base fee. So everyone waits, and the current block becomes empty.

author: Deleted User
content: 5 minutes since last  block on etherscan  ðŸ™

author: Deleted User
content: etherscan stuck, everything is ok

author: andi9314
content: Assuming the block size fluctuation does not stabilize, 1559 leads people to "overpay", just in a different way compared to pre-1559. It's true that people in the same block no longer pay different base fees. But unless you are willing to pay the current base fee (which the average user will often find too high), you need to estimate a base fee that will get you in soon enough. Suppose you don't care about waiting up to 2 minutes, and set a maximum base fee of x. It will sometimes be the case that you get included after 30 seconds and pay x, but you would've gotten in after 90 seconds if you had set a maximum base fee of x/2. If you don't value getting in 60 seconds earlier, you have overpaid by x/2. This is pretty similar to pre-1559 when the average user ended up paying for a higher position inside a block that they did not value.

author: Deleted User
content: can the basefee algorithm be tweaked without a hardfork?

author: andi9314
content:
As a concrete example, consider this screenshot from earlier today. A casual user who was in block 91 (mined by Flexpool.io) "overpaid" for their transaction, unless they valued being in block 91 more than being in block 92. This is because block 91 ended up being less than 50% full, so the base fee became cheaper in block 92. And yet 92 was not full, so they could've gotten in at 92 while paying a lower base fee.
But of course, when block 91 was being mined, there was no way to know that 91 was going to be less than 50% full. So the user might have expected 91 (and the next few blocks) to be more than 50% full, and wanted to get in before fees increased. He guessed wrong, so he paid for faster inclusion that he did not value much. This is not that different from the type of guesswork that users had to do under FPA pre-1559.

I think we'll keep having 100% full blocks quite frequently until making a 100% full block becomes costly for the miner of that block.

author: trent_vanepps
content:
there are a few factors to take into account:

1. people wanting to send their first burn tx >> more congestion
2. people experimenting with new tx types >> more congestion
3. The upgrade is trending on social media, possibly leading to ETH appreciation from buyers who were waiting to see the outcome. market volatility (up or down) generally increases gas prices
4. miners are still targeting a lower gas target than before the fork block. it may take a while for this to stabilize

author: andi9314
content:
There are arguments that having a lot of 100% blocks may not hurt the protocol as long as the average size is 50%. However, when there is oscillation, the average size is likely to be higher than 50% even if the "target" is 50%.
Also, a wild oscillation means gas fees are not predictable for the average user.

author: _____josh_____
content:
Good luck getting the NFT guys to stop paying stupid gas prices.

Regarding why it's bad, consider this:

If gas remains persistently high such that gas burned > block reward, speculators start to aggressively push ETH price higher because of the deflationary effect. 

Assuming gas stays at this elevated level or increases slowly, the cost to non-ETH transactions increases in fiat terms by double. For regular ETH transactions, a user would probably be fine with this increase because their base ETH value is increasing to offset this higher transaction fee. 

However, for someone that's doing a transaction on an ERC20 token, they would not enjoy the same ETH appreciation at all but face constant upward pressure on transaction fees.

Eventually, token activity will die out as seen by recent failed "deflationary" memecoins. Similar effect is expected for other onchain activity.
